name: Primera reunión de R-Ladies Puebla!
description:
AVISO IMPORTANTE: Por motivos ajenos a los organizadores de la reunión nos vemos en la necesidad de modificar la hora y el lugar de nuestra primer reunión. Nos vemos este sábado 24 de agosto a la 1 pm en Workósfera Coworking ubicados en Ave. 5 Oriente # 612, Barrio de los Sapos

No olvides llevar tu laptop !!

¿Conoces R? ¿Lo has utilizado o tienes ganas de aprender a usarlo? Únete a la primer reunión de R-Ladies Puebla, donde charlaremos sobre temas generales como la aplicación de R en diferentes ámbitos profesionales.

El principal objetivo es formar una comunidad de apoyo para aprender a programar y a compartir conocimientos en R en un ambiente tranquilo y amigable.

¿Qué haremos en esta reunión?

-Bienvenida e introducción general acerca de R-Ladies Global

-Breve introducción sobre R

-Brainstorming para próximas reuniones.

Unete con tu laptop. Aunque no es necesario saber R es conveniente instalar R (https://cran.r-project.org) y RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/) antes del taller.

Ambos son gratis y este es tu primer paso para aprender R! Todos son bienvenidos!

name: Segunda Reunion R-Ladies Puebla!
venue_name: Institute of Physics Ing. Luis Rivera Terrazas
description:
Hola a tod@s! L@s invitamos a nuestra segunda reunión de R-Ladies Puebla la cual consistirá en un taller de R para principiantes. Nuestra reunión se llevará a cabo este viernes 4 de octubre en horario de las 16:00 a 18:00 horas en el Centro de Computo del Instituto de Física “Ing. Luis Rivera Terrazas” de la BUAP.

En esta ocasión no es necesario que lleves tu laptop ya que el salón cuenta con computadoras disponibles para usar o si gustas puedes traerla.

El centro de computo cuenta con capacidad para 35 personas, por lo que les agradeceremos confirmen su asistencia lo más pronto posible.

L@s esperamos!

name: Tercera Reunion R-Ladies Puebla!
description:
Hola a tod@s! L@s invitamos a nuestra tercer reunión de R-Ladies Puebla. En esta ocasión nos acompañará Elizabeth Valles, estudiante del doctorado en Ciencias Biomédicas del Instituto de Neurobiología de la UNAM. Eli impartirá un taller de introducción a los paquetes ggplot y tidyverse y nos platicará de su experiencia con R y la utilidad del programa en su campo de estudio. Nuestra reunión se llevará a cabo el sábado 23 de noviembre en horario de las 12:30 a 2:30 horas en la Workósfera Coworking - La Paz

Recuerda traer tu laptop y aunque no es necesario saber R es conveniente instalar R (https://cran.r-project.org), RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/).

Agradeceremos confirmen su asistencia lo más pronto posible.

L@s esperamos!

name: Kick-Off Meet and Greet!
venue_address_1: WRF Data Science Studio, UW Physics/Astronomy Tower, 6th Floor
description:
Welcome to our kick-off meeting of the Seattle R-Ladies chapter. Our first meetup will have a brief intro to R-Ladies Global and the mission of the organization, and then we'll open it up for questions, brainstorming topics for future sessions, and have time for chatting, networking, and getting to know each other. We'll have some snacks to share and some friendly faces!

If you won't be able to make the first meetup but want to let us know who you are and what you're interested in, drop us a line and we can send you our new-chapter survey.

• Important things to know:
R-Ladies code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

name: Happy Hour with R-Ladies Taipei
description:
We have some special guests in town from R-Ladies Taipei: https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/mvpawardprogram/2018/02/15/qa-chiayi-yen/

This event will be a very informal happy hour, with some opportunities for show-and-tell. Bring your laptops and your interesting projects if you have any to show off, or just come to network and hang out with R-Ladies colleagues from around the globe.

Save the date for our next presentation-style meetup: March 19.

name: Intro to Shiny and Web API Data
venue_address_1: WRF Data Science Studio, UW Physics/Astronomy Tower, 6th Floor
description:
• What we'll do
Intro to Accessing Web API Data- Nina Cesare
Intro to Shiny - Bethany Yollin

Lightning Talks:
How to Give a Lightning Talk - Rachael Tatman
Solving a Polyalphabetic Cypher - Nissa Ferm

• What to bring
The web API data will be an interactive demo, so please bring a laptop if you would like to follow along.

name: Happy Hour!
description: First Friday of the Month = Happy Hour! Come hang out with your fellow R-Ladies. Both R related and non r-related chatter are equally welcome!

name: Spatial Data Visualizations
venue_address_1: WRF Data Science Studio, UW Physics/Astronomy Tower, 6th Floor
description:
Aysegul Kramer will present some of her current work visualizing spatial data. Aysegul is looking for some feedback and suggestions, so come prepared to help a fellow R-Lady out!

Afterwards there will be time to bring your own project to work on. You are welcome to work independently or ask for help from your fellow R-Ladies!

name: Happy Hour!
description: First Friday of the Month = Happy Hour! Come hang out with your fellow R-Ladies. Both R related and non r-related chatter are equally welcome!

name: Blogging and Contributing to R Projects
venue_address_1: WRF Data Science Studio, UW Physics/Astronomy Tower, 6th Floor
description: This month we've got an international visitor from Barcelona! Come hear R-Ladies Global Social Master Maëlle Salmon talk about blog content and promotion. In addition, Kara Woo will be giving a practice talk for her keynote talk at CascadiaR on making contributions to established R projects. Help out a fellow R-Lady and give feedback and suggestions to make her talk extra awesome!

name: Workflow and Reproducibility in R
description:
Git is a commonly used tool that is great for improving workflow. Chaya Jones will be giving an intro to git, focused on its integration with Rstudio. A newer tool, Drake, aims to improve aspects of workflow and work reproducibility. Christine Stawitz will be giving an introduction to using Drake.

The meetup is generously being sponsored by Convoy!
Please be aware that the building doors automatically lock at 6pm, so we will have people to let you in and direct you to Convoy's offices.

name: July R-Ladies: Blogdown and Networking!
description:
Isabella Velasquez will be giving a talk on how to create a website using blogdown. We'll follow that with a networking / unconference breakout session - come see us on Slack to vote on breakout topics.

The meetup is generously being sponsored by Convoy!
Please be aware that the building doors automatically lock at 6pm, so we will have people to let you in and direct you to Convoy's offices.

name: August R-Ladies: Problem-solving with R packages, RStudio add-ins
description:
Kerice Doten-Snitker will be giving a talk on some problem-solving she's done using the riverdist package off-label and Rebecca Ferrell will be giving a talk on quality-of-life improving RStudio add-ins.

The meetup is generously being sponsored by Convoy!
Please be aware that the building doors automatically lock at 6pm, so we will have people to let you in and direct you to Convoy's offices.

You are welcome to bring your kids along as needed, please just try to limit disruptions to the group.

name: Data Science Portfolios
description: Learn the do's and don'ts of putting together a data science portfolio with Rachael. We'll be meeting in the Google Fremont office & due to security we do need to get all RSVPs by Friday morning.

name: Less-Traditional Uses of R and More!
description:
Come hear about some non-traditional uses of R, see demos of a couple shiny apps, and more! Plus, there will be pizza.

Schedule:
6:30-6:45pm: Welcome and Socializing
6:45-7:30pm: Liz Kellogg: Project Management Using R
7:30-8pm: Lightning Talks
Kara Woo: Tracking Gas Mileage
Megsie Siple: Shiny Tips and Tricks
Pamela Moriarty: History of R

You are welcome to bring babies and kids along. We just ask that you try to minimize any disruptions to the group.

Thank you to Insight Data Science for hosting and sponsoring our event!

name: Use Cases and Careers: What folks are doing with R at work!
description:
Come hear about how people are using R at work, careers in R, and more!

Schedule:
6:30-6:45pm: Welcome and Socializing
6:45-7:30pm: Careers and Use Cases Talks by Kelly Mistry and Marie Jordan
7:30-8:00pm: Conference connections, potluck planning, bonus networking time

You are welcome to bring babies and kids along. We just ask that you try to minimize any disruptions to the group.

Thank you to Insight Data Science for hosting and sponsoring our event!

name: Holiday Potluck
description:
Join R-ladies for a potluck! Please bring a dish (no drinks to respect Optimism's business) to share and come socialize and hang out with other R-ladies.

Please bring any serving utensils needed for your dish; we will have paper plates and silverware.

name: Data Structures in R: Theory and Applications
description:
Please join us at our January meetup at Fred Hutch (Arnold Building) to learn all about data structures in R and beyond. We will host two speakers, who will give us a background in the basics of data structures in R, and then give us an intro to R's S4 class (often used in Bioconductor packages). This event will be aimed at R-Ladies at all levels of experience.

We will begin with socializing/networking at 6pm. Talks will begin at 6:30pm.

Pizza will be provided.
Please bring your laptop if you would like to participate in a coding exercise.

Speakers:
*new speaker*
Rachael Tatman is a data scientist at Kaggle with a linguistics PhD she occasionally dusts off and gets some use from. Her professional interests include natural language processing, statistics, fairness accountability and transparency in machine learning and, of course, R.

Chao-Jen Wong is a Bioinformatician at Tapscott Lab in Fred Hutch working on discovery of cure for Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy. She is also an organizer of FredHutch Bioinformatics Interest Group (FHBIg.io). Prior to that, she was an R programmer and core member of the Bioconductor Project. She has a PhD in Applied Mathematics from Claremont Graduate University. When she is not working or studying, she enjoys cooking and hauling her kids around town with her electric bike.

name: Intro to Shiny Workshop
venue_address_1: WRF Data Science Studio, UW Physics/Astronomy Tower, 6th Floor
description:
Join us for a hands-on workshop that will introduce you to building a web app in R using Shiny taught by Megsie Siple.

Please bring a laptop with Rstudio. Unfortunately, we do not have funding to provide lunch, so please bring lunch along or plan on purchasing it. There are plenty of nearby options and we will definitely have a lunch break!

We expect this workshop to fill and have a waitlist, as we are aware many people have been wanting to learn Shiny! To make sure that as many people are able to attend and benefit as possible, we ask that if you RSVP yes, you are definitively planning to come. If your plans change, please do update your RSVP.

Prereq: A basic knowledge of R. You absolutely do not need to be a high-powered R user to benefit from this workshop! If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to send us a message. We are committed to making this accessible to as wide a range of R skills as possible.

If you have an app you know you'd like to build, feel free to bring code, data, or an outline of what you want to do. This workshop is open to anyone who wants to expand their Shiny skills, but will be targeted towards people who are just starting out.

name: Women in Computing: History and Present
description:
Come join us at our March R-Ladies Meetup!

This month, we'll be celebrating and talking about the trans*, nonbinary, agender, genderqueer and female people who have gone before us and inspired us with their programming prowess.

From Ada Lovelace to current mentors, we encourage you to bring fun stories, book recommendations, advice for mentors and mentees, and your own awesome accomplishments. (Stories and experiences of people of color are especially encouraged!) We'll be breaking out into small groups to share these stories and see where the conversation goes. Please don't feel you have to bring a story to participate; these will be loose, fun, and adaptable groups!

The meeting will wind up with an rstudio::conf watch party, the lecture TBD. Please feel free to reach out if there's a particular topic you're interested in.

Watch this space for further details as we get closer to the date.

name: Transition to Data Science
description:
Join PyLadies, R-Ladies, Women in Data Science (WiDS), and Insight Data Science to learn about transitioning to a career in data science and the variety of roles that full under the title 'data scientist'!

To help us plan, please RSVP directly on the WiDS meetup page:
http://meetu.ps/e/GBzH9/GRKLB/f

We'll start with lightning talks from panelists on what their job as a data scientist entails, which will be followed by a panel discussion focused on how the panelists moved into the field and their experiences in it. There will, of course, be plenty of time for questions from attendees!

Panelists include:
- Lisa Qian
Data Science Manager at Airbnb, transitioned to DS 6 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/lisa-qian-98b04326/
- Annette Taberner-Miller
Data Science Manager at Indeed, transitioned to DS 8 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/annette-taberner-miller/
- Susan Fung
Sr. Data Analyst at Liberty Mutual, transitioned to DS 1 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/susanfung/
- Nupur Mehta
Data Scientist II at Redfin, transitioned to DS 2 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/nupurmehta4/
- Gina Schmalzle
Senior Data Scientist at Nordstrom, transitioned to DS 4 yrs ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/ginaschmalzle/
- Heather Nolis
Machine Learning Engineer at T-Mobile, transitioned to DS 1 yr ago
https://www.linkedin.com/in/heatherwensler/

Many thanks to Insight Data Science for sponsoring this event!

Schedule:
6:15-6:45: arrive, pizza, drinks
6:45-7:15: lightning talks on what data scientist jobs can include
7:15-8: panel
8-8:30: networking

name: Learning R and Building Community
description:
Mark your calendars! This month we will hear from 2 people about their pathways to learning R and the great community-building that happened along the way. Redfin has kindly offered to host us in their space in downtown Seattle and will be providing pizza.

Speakers:
* Stefanie Butland, Community Manager at rOpenSci
* Malisa Smith, Bioinformatician at University of Washington

Stefanie Butland:
I am the Community Manager for an organization of R practitioners...but I am not an R practitioner. For the first 1.5 years in my job, this was a feature, but lately it has felt more like a bug. In this talk I will introduce rOpenSci, our packages, and our system for transparent software peer review, and then share my story of starting to learn R by (not so) passive absorption of information and best practices from R-Ladies, rOpenSci, and the broader R world.

Malisa Smith:
Flow cytometry is commonly used by biologists to measure the abundance of specific molecules in millions of cells, while retaining information at the single-cell level. The resulting high-dimensional, high-throughput datasets have led to the development of unique software for analyzing flow cytometry data. I will talk about how I learned to use open source R packages for analyzing flow data, and I hope that my experience will help other people navigate the landscape of flow cytometry analysis tools and online software resources in general.

name: The Ministry of Silly Talks + SuperMeetup Social Hour
description:
*RSVP HERE: https://www.meetup.com/Seattle-PyLadies/events/261516172/ Centralized RSVPs help the organizers plan, thank you for helping us!*

Lots of folks in town for SSDS in Bellevue from 29 May - 1 June. Lovely time for a larger get together!

5:00PM - 6:00PM - Social Hour w/ Food

6:00PM - 7:00PM - The Ministry of Silly Talks!

Please sign up to give a 5-minute lightning talk on whatever you want (non-technical talks welcome!) here: http://bit.ly/pyladies-ministry-of-silly-talks

7:00PM - 8:00PM - More Social Hour (optional speed networking round)

name: R-Ladies Social in SLU
description: Join us for an R-Ladies social event at Brave Horse Tavern in South Lake Union. Connect and catch up with other R-Ladies members. We've planned out some great events for the rest of 2019, which we'll review at the social, and we'd love to hear your thoughts on future events.

name: Seattle Summer Lightning Talks!
description:
Is it too sunny out? Are you missing the Seattle rain? Get your fix at an R-Ladies Lightning Talk Session! Lightning talks are informal, 5 minute talks on anything R, data science, or tech related. Examples are:

* Your favorite R learning resource
* How you use R at work
* Your favorite R package

We would love for you to be a speaker! Please sign up here: https://forms.gle/ZevMUKrNJLWdhkEu5

For a wonderful reference from a previous speaker, please see Rachael Tatman's deck on How to Prepare & Give A ⚡Lightning⚡ Talk:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1nod6zgs1DQczpxWg_8opKS7gDmzWMmjMNWIxKzjhEWM/edit#slide=id.p

Many thanks to Sage Bionetworks for hosting us!

Thank you and see you soon!

name: Code Reviews! Learn how to review code & submit code for review
description:
How do you review code from a data science project? Often, the goal of code review is to ensure that new code is free of bugs, efficient, well-documented, and maintainable. Code review is also an excellent opportunity to learn from others and get feedback on your work. However, practices vary widely from academia to industry and standards are mostly non-existent.

At this event, we will hear from R-Ladies members about best practices for code review, how code review is conducted in their workplace, and then we'll practice code review in small groups.

Speakers:
Lauren Wolfe, Research Data Specialist at Fred Hutch
Carrie Bennette, Principal Quantitative Scientist at Flatiron

We are looking for R-Ladies members to share code that they'd like feedback on for the group exercise. Please comment in the event discussion thread if you have code you'd like to bring to the meeting.

Pizza & refreshments will be provided by Fred Hutch.
Please feel free to bring children if childcare is unavailable.

name: Happy Hour Hangout
description:
Join other R-ladies for a low key social event! Chatting about R and non-R topics are equally welcome! :)

Warning: Happy hour prices at Cactus actually end at 6pm, so feel free to show up a few minutes early to grab a discounted snack or drink. Organizers may just not be around until 6.

name: Spooky data stories
description:
Data formatting hell? Machine learning horror? We’re looking for 5-10 minute presentations about your scariest data stories and how you solved them using R.

We would love for you to be a speaker! Please sign up here: https://forms.gle/xaNbcku6PAnLRuQ19

For a wonderful reference from a previous speaker, please see Rachael Tatman's deck on How to Prepare & Give A ⚡Lightning⚡ Talk:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1nod6zgs1DQczpxWg_8opKS7gDmzWMmjMNWIxKzjhEWM/edit#slide=id.p

Many thanks to Sage Bionetworks for hosting us and providing pizza!

Thank you and see you soon!

name: Project-oriented workflows in R
venue_address_1: WRF Data Science Studio, UW Physics/Astronomy Tower, 6th Floor
description:
Kara Woo will present on project-oriented workflows in R. The workshop will cover the first two modules of the two-day What They Forgot to Teach You About R workshop (https://rstudio-conf-2020.github.io/what-they-forgot/). This workshop is designed for experienced R and RStudio users who want to (re)design their R lifestyle. You'll learn holistic workflows that address the most common sources of friction in data analysis.

You should take this workshop if: you've been using R for a while and you feel like writing R code is not what's holding you back the most. You've realized that you have more pressing "meta" problems that no one seems to talk about: You want to know how to divide your work into projects and scripts and how to share your work with others.

name: R-Ladies 2019 Hot Chocolate Happy Hour
description:
Come celebrate the end of the year with a hot chocolate happy hour at Kakao! ☕✨

📅 Year in Review
Let's explore what we covered this year, what awesome tools we learned about, and what amazing things our fellow R-Ladies have accomplished!

👯 Organizer updates
A few updates for next year, and a call for those who are interested to join us as organizers! It's a wonderful, fufilling experience.

💡 Ideas for next year
Is there an R/data science topic you wish you knew more about? Or something super cool that you did that you want to share? Let us know! We're always welcoming new ideas.

⬢ Hex Competition voting
Throughout the month of November, we are holding a hex design competition. Represent our city on a hex for all to see! Please submit your entries here! http://bit.ly/seahex

Thank you for an amazing 2019 and we look forward to having fun with R together in 2020! 💜

name: R configuration and purrr
venue_name: University Branch - The Seattle Public Library
description:
Kara Woo will present a workshop on R configuration, maintaining R, and how to repeat yourself with purrr. The workshop will cover the 5th and 8th modules of the two-day What They Forgot to Teach You About R workshop (https://rstudio-conf-2020.github.io/what-they-forgot/).

This workshop is designed for experienced R and RStudio users who want to (re)design their R lifestyle. You should take this workshop if you’ve been using R for a while, you feel like writing R code is not what’s holding you back the most, and you want to learn more about your R installation.

This is a hands-on workshop, so please bring a laptop with a current version of R and RStudio installed. RSVPing helps us know how many people to expect, but is not required.

This event is NOT sponsored by The Seattle Public Library.

name: Tidy Tuesday and Pizza at Fred Hutch
description:
Tidy Tuesday is a weekly social data project in R organized by the R4DS Online Learning Community. Join R-Ladies on Tuesday, February 18th to learn more about Tidy Tuesday and to work on this week's project.

From the Tidy Tuesday website:
"Every week we post a raw dataset, a chart or article related to that dataset, and ask you to explore the data. While the dataset will be 'tamed', it will not always be tidy! As such you might need to apply various R for Data Science techniques to wrangle the data into a true tidy format. The goal of TidyTuesday is to apply your R skills, get feedback, explore other’s work, and connect with the greater #RStats community! As such we encourage everyone of all skills to participate!"

More information and the data for each week is available on the Tidy Tuesday website (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Details:
6pm - 8pm
Fred Hutch Sze Conference Room in the Thomas Building
(Note that this is a different building than past R-Ladies events. See map here for directions: https://www.fredhutch.org/content/dam/www/about-us/contact-us/FredHutch_Map_09_2019.pdf)
Pizza provided by Fred Hutch

name: Hacknight at Kakao
description:
About:

A hacknight is a free-style coding environment, where a group of individuals come together to work on various projects in one space, with the purpose to ask one another questions, ranging from specific troubleshooting to conceptual. These projects can be group projects or individual.

Details:

Bring your code and laptop and get ready to enjoy some coffee/hot chocolate and a good working environment.

I will be working on making an R package from code I’ve written over the years. I will be following this tutorial, which anyone can follow step-by-step even without any specific code to add to a package. http://web.mit.edu/insong/www/pdf/rpackage_instructions.pdf

If you do not have a specific project but would like to join, you could start (or finish if you attended the Rladies meetup on Feb 18th) your Tidy Tuesday plots. Tidy Tuesday datasets can be found at https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday and you can follow this vignette from the awesome ggpubr package to make some pretty plots quickly https://rpkgs.datanovia.com/ggpubr/index.html.

For more plotting ideas/vignettes, check out http://www.sthda.com/english/articles/24-ggpubr-publication-ready-plots and built-in datasets are listed here: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/r-built-in-data-sets.

name: pRedicaments in R: An R-Ladies Remote Rendezvous
description:
Join R-Ladies Seattle for our first remote meeting on debugging and getting help! Inspired by Jenny Bryan's keynote at rstudio::conf (link below), we will take a deeper dive into how to resolve error messages in R.

We have 2 wonderful speakers who will be presenting.

_Christine Stawitz_
* I'll discuss my process for sifting through the (often less-than-helpful) documentation that comes with R packages, including function reference, vignettes, and GitHub issue forums.
* I'm a contractor at ECS Federal in support of NOAA Fisheries' Office of Science and Technology. I work on improving coding, documentation, and sharing practices for the software NOAA and academic fisheries scientists use to manage marine resources.

_Katie Jolly_
* I'll talk about using the {reprex} package for creating reproducible examples. This package makes it easier to write clear, concise, and readable code questions that will get a more helpful response in return.
* I am a data analyst at Ookla. I am interested in spatial data, information design, and civic data projects.

Details:
* We will send out conference call information to attendees who have RSVP'd "Yes" to this event. The call will be taking place over zoom.
* Thank you to Ookla for helping us get set up with zoom!

Link to Jenny Bryan's talk in case you'd like to view it before our meeting (not required!):
https://resources.rstudio.com/rstudio-conf-2020/object-of-type-closure-is-not-subsettable-jenny-bryan

name: R-Ladies Edinburgh Introductory meeting
venue_name: The psychology department of the university of Edinburgh
description:
Hi everyone!

We are finally hosting our first R-Ladies Edinburgh meeting. It will take place at 7 George Square, room G.32. We will upload a survey soon for you to complete, to have a general idea of who you are and what do you want to learn. If you cannot make it this time, please respond to the survey as this is important for the rest of our meetings and to decide what we will do in the future.

We hope this time is alright for the majority of you - please indicate your availability in the survey for future meetings!

This meeting is for:

- Meet each other.
- Discuss the results of the survey to decide what we want to get from R-Ladies Edinburgh.
- R-Ladies code of conduct.

You can also email us if you have any suggestions/questions.

name: ggplot2 workshop
description: We are very excited to invite you to a ggplot2 workshop conducted by Dr Mine Cetinkaya-Rundel, who is a world renowned statistician. We will have 40 slots, and we need you to bring your laptop with you. If you don't have one, please let us know in advance so we can get one for you. Please RSVP.

name: R for Open Science
venue_name: Room 1.17, Dugald Stewart Building, The University of Edinburgh
description: We want to invite you to our next R-Ladies Edinburgh event! Dr Candice Coker Morey will speak about how to use R for Open Science. Dr Coker Morey is a Senior Lecturer at Cardiff University, editor of the Journal of Cognition, and a self professed Open Science enthusiast!

name: Key Ingredients for Predictive Analytics with R: ‘caret’ and ‘parsnip’
description:
Our next speaker is Dr Anastasia Ushakova. She has a PhD in Computational Social Science from UCL and is passionate about both development and application of statistical methods as well as promoting those to a new generation of applied researchers.

During the workshop, we will look at an overview of a set of models that can be used in R for prediction or classification tasks. These will include linear and logistic models, tree methods, neural networks and other common machine learning/data science tools.

The packages ‘caret’ and ‘parsnip’ will be introduced to fit the models, compare the performance and provide quick visualisations for the overall assessment. This workshop will be useful for both an industry and an academic audience that are interested with predictive analytics and wish to get hands on practice in model fitting in R.

name: Introduction to Bayesian Statistical Modelling using brms
description:
We are super pleased to invite you to our workshop "Introduction to Bayesian Statistical Modelling using brms". In this two-day workshop, we will learn some basics about Bayesian statistics, with a focus on using a Bayesian approach to statistical modelling. We will use brms package by Paul Bürkner, which uses Stan.

On the first day, we will have an intro to Bayesian statistics and statistical modelling. We will be introduced to brms using simple variants of the general linear model, and multi-level models, with a normal response distribution.

On the second day, we will take a look at the binomial and Poisson distribution for count data, and learn when we should used them and how to do so using brms.

The workshop will have small lectures and some practical exercises so the participants can fit their own models with brms.

This workshop will be facilitated by Marie Beisemann. She's about to start her Phd in Statistics at the Technical University of Dortmund, Germany, right after finishing he Master's degree in psychology at the University of Münster. She's (really) passionate about sharing her knowledge about brms and Bayes with us, and we're super excited to have her here!

P. S., if you will attend this workshop, we really need you to install brms beforehand.

name: R Markdown – from RStudio to Word/PDF/website with a single push of a button
description:
At this workshop you will learn 2 things:

• What is Markdown and how to get directly from R into Word documents, PDF reports, websites, or presentations
• How to work with R Notebooks (twin sister of R Markdown) – an interactive alternative to R scripts

Suitable for R newbies: working examples will be provided, no on-the-spot R code writing needed.

Experienced users will also benefit as we'll point out the most up to date functionality within R Markdown and RStudio.

This workshop's speaker, Riinu, is a data scientist with an interdisciplinary background. She works at the Centre for Medical Informatics.
www.riinu.me

name: rstudio::conf 2020 Watch Party
venue_name: Appleton Tower, The University of Edinburgh
description:
With the support of RStudio, we are delighted to co-host an rstudio::conf 2020 watch party with the Edinburgh R useR Group.

The watch party will start with a pre-game event starting on 29 Jan 2020 at 16:00. This live-streamed pre-game event will feature short interviews with folks from RStudio as well as the wider R-Community. During this event, the attendees at the watch parties will have an opportunity to interact with the host and guests in real-time. The pre-game event will lead directly into the keynote and session live-streams.

During this meetup we'll watch the keynote from J.J. Allaire (RStudio) and Fernanda Viegas and Martin Wattenberg (Google Brain). Watch party attendees will be able to submit questions to the keynoters and we'll have some RStudio swag to give away!

Feel free to join us for as long as you want. You don't need to be the whole three hours to attend.

name: Scraping and Visualising Twitter Data with Anna Henschel
description:
In this short, hands-on workshop we are going to scrape and visualize our own Twitter data by understanding the basics of text wrangling and by taking advantage of the amazing {tidytext} and {rtweet} packages. By the end of the workshop, you will be able to see if you tweet mostly positive or negative content, and you will be able to plot the most frequent words in a wordcloud. Don't worry if you do not have your own Twitter account - there will be an alternative provided.

Anna Henschel is a third year PhD candidate at the University of Glasgow, where she conducts research in the Social Brain in Action Lab on the ERC-funded Social Robots project. She has a B.Sc. in Psychology from Konstanz University and a M.Sc. cum laude from the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam in Cognitive Neuropsychology. Her feminist activism and work as a STEM ambassador was recently honoured with the YWCA 30 Under 30 Inspirational Women Scotland award. She uses R in her PhD and also just for fun.

You can find her on Twitter (@AnnaHenschel) and check out the workshop Twitter account (@beautiful_hack).

name: [ONLINE] Scalable Automatic Machine Learning in R with H2O with Erin LeDell
venue_name: Bayes Centre, The University of Edinburgh
description:
**UPDATE** We are moving this event online, at the same time and day. We will send a Zoom link for the call day prior to the event. Hope you can join us online!

Dr. Erin LeDell is the Chief Machine Learning Scientist at H2O.ai, where she leads the development of an open-source, automatic machine learning (AutoML) platform. Before joining H2O.ai, she worked as a data scientist and software engineer and founded DataScientific, Inc. She’s also the founder of the non-profit Women in Machine Learning & Data Science (WiMLDS.org) organization and co-founder of the R-Ladies Global organization. She received her Ph.D. from UC Berkeley where her research focused on machine learning and statistical computing.

**Scalable Automatic Machine Learning in R with H2O**

The focus of this presentation is scalable and automatic machine learning in R using the H2O machine learning platform. H2O is an open-source, distributed machine learning platform is designed to scale to very large datasets that may not fit into RAM on a single machine. We will provide a brief overview of the field of Automatic Machine Learning, followed by a detailed look inside H2O’s AutoML algorithm. H2O AutoML provides an easy-to-use interface that automates data pre-processing, training and tuning a large selection of candidate models (including multiple stacked ensemble models for superior model performance), and due to the distributed nature of the H2O platform, H2O AutoML can scale to very large datasets. The result of the AutoML run is a “leaderboard” of H2O models which can be easily exported for use in production. R code examples are available on GitHub for participants to follow along on their laptops.

--

Q: Are men welcome to attend this event?
A: Our primary mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. ***As such, we strongly encourage that all men who attend this event have a female or non-binary sponsor. Please contact [masked] if you have questions.***

Additionally, please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

name: R-Ladies Nijmegen launch event
description:
It is time for the launch event of R-Ladies Nijmegen!

During the launch event we will introduce you to R-Ladies (who we are, what we do, why it's important), discuss the results of our survey (see below), and of course meet all of you! We will be providing some drinks and snacks!

A huge thank you to R consortium for sponsoring this event and to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting it!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SCHEDULE
18:30 Doors open & Welcome
18:45 Intro to R-Ladies
19:00 Survey results
19:15 Meet your fellow R-Ladies!
19:45 Networking & Snacks
20:30 Wrap up

SURVEY
We have prepared a short survey to learn more about you and how we can make future meet-ups maximally useful to you. You can find this here: https://goo.gl/forms/mWvPoviu4GbhLxP53

Please fill in the survey even if you can't make it to our launch event -- you will be helping us organise our next meetings around topics you are interested in and at a time that is convenient to you.

CODE OF CONDUCT

Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Looking forward to meeting all of you!

name: R Markdown workshop - All levels!
description:
The time for the second R-Ladies Nijmegen event is here! In this event we will be focusing on R Markdown, an easy way to combine text and code that keeps your workflow reproducible!

This workshop will will start with an introduction to R Markdown followed by a hands-on session. It will be accessible to R Ladies of all levels :)

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R Studio installed. You can easily install R Markdown like any other R package, just run this code:
install.packages("rmarkdown")

It would be nice (and things will go faster) if you download the materials for the workshop before the actual workshop. You can find these in the R Ladies Nijmegen GitHub repository at https://github.com/RLadiesNijmegen/RMarkdown

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
A huge thank you to R consortium for sponsoring this event and to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting it!

name: R Shiny workshop
description:
Hello R Ladies!!

It's time for our third event and this one's special! This event will be led by a guest, Dr. Suthira Owlarn, coming all the way from the MPI for Molecular Biology in Muenster. Suthira will be teaching us how to use R Shiny, a way to build interactive web applications using R.

Shiny is a popular framework for building R-powered interactive web apps and dashboards – and a great way to present your data/analyses to the world! Its ease-of-use makes it beginner-friendly, while its flexibility and extendibility allow more advanced programmers to make use of various skills (e.g. javascript, test-writing).

Based on the initial R Ladies Nijmegen survey, the current plan for the workshop assumes fundamental R skills, but no previous shiny experience. It’ll be a presentation with short exercises, followed by a longer hands-on session and Q&A.

You can find a more general R concepts refresher to make sure you’re ready for the workshop here: https://github.com/sowla/2019-shiny-intro-workshop-Nijmegen-RLadies

About the speaker: Suthira Owlarn is a biologist at the Max Planck Institute in Münster. After finishing her PhD, she decided to learn a little R and immediately fell in love! Soon, she waved goodbye to the bench and is now having fun diving into the world of data analysis, exploring R packages and building shiny apps.

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R Studio installed and with the 'shiny' package.

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
A huge thank you to the IMPRS for Language Sciences (www.mpi.nl/education) and R consortium for sponsoring this event and to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting it!

name: Visualise your data with R -- All levels welcome!
description:
We're very excited to announce our next workshop on data visualization!

In this hands-on event, Limor Raviv will teach you how to create effective and beautiful plots using ggplot2, as well as some other neat packages.

You'll learn how to present your raw data in different ways to make the best of your graphs, how to plot your summarized data, and how to visualize your regression models' results.

The workshop will also use R markdown, giving you all a quick refresher on how to use this handy tool!

The full code for the workshop can be found here: https://github.com/Limor-Raviv/Data-Visualization

SCHEDULE
18:30 Doors open
18:45 Intro to Data Visualisation Principles -- Laurel Brehm
19:00 Interactive Data Visualisation workshop -- Limor Raviv
20:30 Event ends

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R Studio installed.
You'll also need to install some packages - you can simply do that on the spot, or if you like you can also set it up in advance (take a look at the code on GitHub for the list of required packages).

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
A huge thank you to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting this event!

name: Towards reproducible science: Power analysis
description:
Want to make sure that you can draw conclusions from your results? Or instill more trust in your research findings? Or make sure that any results you generate are reproducible? If so, come along and learn how to do power analysis in R! Power analysis is vital in today's age, where we aren't always sure if we can trust any finding from any data. With enough power, we know that we have the ability to detect certain effects if they are there, giving more trust to the research process. And, even better, with enough power other can also replicate your work!

We'll have more detailed information soon about the content of the session.

SCHEDULE
18:30-18:45. Introduction to power and reproducibility. Laurel Brehm & Eirini Zormpa
18:45-19:15. Code walkthrough: Power calculations based on earlier research. Marianne de Heer Kloots
19:15-20:30. Live coding: Writing power calculation functions and simulating data. Laurel Brehm

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R Studio installed.
You'll also need to install some packages - you can simply do that on the spot, or if you like you can also set it up in advance (we'll let you know soon what they will be!).

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
A huge thank you to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting this event!

name: R-Ladies Lightning talks!
description:
Hi everyone! We're back from the summer break with a special event -- Lightning Talks! Come learn about what your R-Ladies community is doing and be inspired about different ways of using R!

SCHEDULE
18:30. Doors open
18:45-19:00. Intro to R-Ladies
19:00-20:00. Lightning talks:

* How to use colourblind-friendly palettes - Laurel Brehm

* Cluster analysis in R - Iris Monster

* Eye-tracking data in R: the basics - Francie Manhardt

* An intro to integrating git into your R workflow - Greta Kaufeld

* A brief introduction to exploring movement data (GPS) in R - Marlee Tucker

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment

A huge thank you to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting this event!

name: Handle and analyze eye-tracking data in R – All levels welcome!
description:
Are you planning to process and analyze eye-tracking or are just curious how it works?
In this workshops we will cover some basics of eye-tracking: from an example of an eye-tracking experiment to data processing, plotting, and some basic analyses. You don’t need to know anything about eye-tracking but some basic R skills would be good.

Come along to learn how to analyse eye-tracking data in a workshop given by Francie Manhardt!

Francie is a PhD student at the Radboud University and Max Planck Institute Nijmegen and passionate about sign languages, eye-tracking and R. During her PhD she combined all three – the dream! Over the years, she has conducted many eye-tracking studies and after analyzing her first in excel she is the happiest person to have found R and tackles eye-gaze data in R ever since.

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R Studio installed.

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
A huge thank you to the Gelderland Zuid library for hosting this event!

name: Analyse your data using GAMs in R – All levels welcome!
venue_name: Orikami Data Science for Healthcare & Lifesciences, Personalized Healthcare
description:
Have you heard about generalised additive models (GAMs) and would like to know more about how to use them? Come along to this workshop to get an introduction to GAMs: what they are and when and how to use them.

PROGRAMME
Note the different day (Tuesday) and location (Orikami)!

The event will start at 18:30.
Data Scientist Inez Wijnands will start us off with an introduction to the work that Orikami does and then Evelien will tell us all about GAMs!

Inez Wijnands works as a data scientist at Orikami. She studied Artificial Intelligence with a focus on Computational Cognitive Neuroscience at the Radboud University. At Orikami she uses 'AI in healthcare', combining her main interests.

Dr. Evelien Heyselaar is an Assistant Professor in AI and Communication Science at the Radboud University.

Drinks and snacks will be provided by Orikami.

REQUIREMENTS
Don't forget to bring your (fully charged!) laptop with R and R Studio installed.

You can download the materials from: https://github.com/RLadiesNijmegen/GAMMs

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct -- we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment
https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

SPONSORS
We are very grateful to Orikami for sponsoring this event!

name: R Ladies Netherlands Book Club - Advanced R Chapter 2
description:
The R Ladies chapters of the Netherlands are partnering up! Starting in April, we'll be hosting an online book club. Our first book is going to be Hadley Wickham's Advanced R. Meetings will take place on zoom every two weeks.

In this first meeting, we'll introduce the idea of having an R-Ladies book club and then Laurel Brehm from R Ladies Nijmegen will present the key points of Chapter 2 (Names and values). After that, we'll go through the exercises together and help each other clear up any doubts and get over any hurdles :) Make sure to read the chapter in advance!

You can find the Advanced R book here: https://adv-r.hadley.nz/
The link to the zoom meeting will be provided closer to the date.
You can find the full schedule and more information here: https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club

name: R-Ladies Newcastle launch event and social
description:
Please join us for our launch event!

We will introduce R-Ladies Newcastle and its organisers for our first meeting, and ask for feedback from you about events you would like to attend. We will then visualise your responses at the meeting, and socialise afterwards, so we can start building our local community of R-Ladies. Pizza and drinks provided. ​We welcome all levels of R users.

R-Ladies is an inclusive group that welcomes everyone identifying as women or marginalised genders.

UPDATE: Please fill in our survey before the meetup if possible: https://forms.gle/y5UYg67ejczBfCJZA If you can't attend the event, you can still fill in the survey. Thank you!

UPDATE 2: Thanks to our sponsors Sage there will be pizza at the meetup!

We look forward to meeting you!

R-Ladies Newcastle Organising Team

name: June meetup
description:
This will be a tutorial session where you can improve your R skills! Please bring a laptop. We will prepare handouts for the meetup.

For the first part of the session, we will start off with an introduction to R, since we have many beginners in the group. If you are an advanced user, it would be great if you could come along to the first part too, and share your knowledge. For the second part, we will do some more advanced plotting.

There will be some pizza, as well as soft drinks.

Timings:

18:00 Meet and mingle
18:15 Start first part - introduction to R
19:00 Break
19:15 Start second part - advanced plotting
20:00 Optional pub visit

Please have R and RStudio installed on your laptop. The tutorials can be found at github.com/rbolam/RLadiesNCL.

name: July meetup - data visualisation
description:
This will be a tutorial session where you can improve your R skills! Please bring a laptop. If you do not have a laptop, let us know because we have a few for people to borrow. This meetup will be suitable both for beginners and advanced R users.

We will mainly work with the package ggplot2. For beginners, we will introduce the package and its functions, with exercises for you to practice. We will cover how to make different types of plots, how to make subplots, and how to fully customise your plots.

For advanced users, we will look at some more specialised packages, to make ridge plots, use different themes, arrange all your plots nicely, and make chloropleth maps.

Timings:
18:00 Meet and mingle
18:15 Introduction to ggplot2, additional packages, and where to find the resources
18:45 Start tutorials
20:00 Optional pub visit at the Earl of Pitt Street

Please have R and RStudio installed on your laptop.

We will use room 2.022 in the Urban Sciences Building.

If you have any questions, comments or suggestions, you can email us at [masked]

name: August meetup- Summer Social
description:
August meetup – Summer Social

We will be building on what we’ve learnt so far and getting to know each other better!

This month’s meetup will be a chance for our members to build on the skills we worked on in the last meetup using Tidy Tuesday data. More advanced members are also encouraged to attend and show us what they can do with the data.

For the second half of the meetup, we’ll be encouraging you to put your laptops away and get socialising! If so inclined members are welcome to Bring Your Own Bottle, we as organisers will for sure be kicking back with a glass of wine but feel free to bring the beverage of your choice for this part of the meetup. We’d love to hear about your journey with R (whether a newbie or an experienced user) and share experiences as minority genders in the programming space.

Timings:
18:00 - 20:00 Summer Social
20:00 optional visit to Earl of Pitt Street

We will be in room 2.022 in the Urban Sciences Building.

Please arrive with R and R Studio installed on your laptop. If you would like to be loaned a laptop before the meetup, please get in touch with us in the comments below to request one. We’d appreciate being given at least a few days notice

name: September meetup
description:
September Meeting – Guest tutorial on linear mixed effects models (LMEMs)

This month's meetup will feature a guest tutorial led by Bodo Winter (http://bodowinter.com/) on running Linear Mixed Effects Models in R. He is a lecturer in Linguistics at the University of Birmingham and an accomplished teacher of statistics and R known for his clear and accessible teaching style.

In the first hour of the meetup, Bodo will lead his tutorial, which will be geared toward somewhat more advanced users of R who are interested in applying LMEMs to their data. However, we invite users at all levels to come follow along and ask questions. Don't be worried about it being too advanced -- this tutorial will be useful for people at all levels!

In the second half, we will have pizza and we encourage you to Bring Your Own Bottle (of any sort of beverage you fancy) to enjoy or to share. This will be a time to talk through practical applications of LMEMs for your own work and ask questions of Bodo and the more advanced users. This will be a great opportunity for people comfortable with statistics to ask more advanced methodological questions *as well as* for people who are more new to LMEMs and R to consolidate the tutorial material.

Timings:
18:00 - 19:00 LMEM Tutorial
19:00 - 20:00 Question and Answers and Pizza

We will be in the Urban Sciences Building again (2.022) and the room will be accessible through the main entrance to the building.

Please arrive with R and R Studio installed on your laptop. If you would like to be loaned a laptop before the meetup, please get in touch with us in the comments below to request one. We’d appreciate being given at least a few days notice.

name: October meetup
description:
We will be having a series of lightning talks from our R-Ladies community! We’d love to hear from as many of you as possible on how you’ve used R, no matter your level of experience.

It should be an excellent chance to hear about the breadth of R use which is happening in Newcastle.

There will be talks on:
- Using R for eye tracking while reading
- What is Bioinformatics?
- Using factors in R
- Working with satellite data to map forests & forest quality
- Topic modelling
- Disentangling the drivers of predators on coral reefs
- Modelling hierarchical data for children in schools for a language intervention study
and more!

As always, there will be pizza too! We will meet in room 4.005.

If you have any questions, comments or suggestions, you can email us at [masked]

name: November meetup: THE PURDUR EDIT
description:
ENTRANCE IS VIA THE BACK DOOR
Due to Purdur (restrictions placed on government employees in the run up to an election) our scheduled speakers are unable to give public talks.

To stick with our theme of government data science we will instead be running a hands on workshop to investigate election data. We will work in teams to ensure that the workshop is suitable for all levels of R users so come along with a positive attitude and lets get stuck in to some data wrangling and data viz.

Please bring laptops with you for this event. If you need access to a laptop please inform the organisers by Friday 08th of Nov.
We will meet in room 2.022 in the Urban Sciences Building. There will be pizza and soft drinks!

ENTRANCE IS VIA THE BACK DOOR

name: R-Ladies Christmas social and yearly roundup!
description:
We’ll be having our final Meetup of the year to look back on all the great stuff that’s happened since we began back in May.

Christmasy snacks and pizza will be on offer and your encouraged to bring your own bottle. We’d love to hear your feedback from this year so far, what you’d like to see next and what your R goals are for next year!

If you’ve not made it to a meetup this year, then this will be a great opportunity to get to know the community we’ve built so far.

Room 2.022- Entrance will be via the rear door

name: March meetup - data wrangling using the tidyverse
description:
This will be a tutorial session where you can improve your R skills! Please bring a laptop. This meetup will be suitable both for beginners and intermediate R users.

We will work with tidyverse packages and learn how to do data wrangling in R, for example how to change the format of your data, how to combine different dataframes, summarising your data, and dealing with factor levels.

We will meet at 6pm, and then everyone can work on the tutorials. Help will be available.

Please have R and RStudio installed on your laptop, and install the tidyverse (install.packages("tidyverse") ). There will be only limited sockets at the venue, so please charge your laptop before the event.

Location: The Greenhouse, ground floor of Northumbria University Students’ Union.

If you have any questions, comments or suggestions, you can email us at [masked]

name: Panel session and meetup pre-SatRday
description:
R-Ladies Newcastle are pleased to announce we will be hosting a panel session with Julia Silge (https://juliasilge.com/about/), a data scientist and software engineer at R Studio, and  Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel (http://www2.stat.duke.edu/~mc301/) a Senior Lecturer in the School of Mathematics at University of Edinburgh and Data Scientist and Professional Educator at RStudio.
 
The event will be an opportunity for R-Ladies to meet up prior to the SatRdays event taking place the next day, so if you’re in Newcastle the night before please come along. If you’re worried about attending SatRdays alone, then this will be a great chance to meet a few friendly faces who you’ll recognise the next day. Alternatively, if you’d been on the fence of making the journey to Newcastle hopefully this will act as an extra enticement!
 
We're so excited for SatRdays and hope to see as many R-Ladies members as possible. Tickets can be purchased from: https://newcastle2020.satrdays.org/

About the session:
6:00-7:00pm Panel session (approx.)
7:00-8pm Networking
 
We need your questions!
 
The panel session will be a chance to ask Julia and Mine about their career history as R-Ladies and the different focuses their careers have had. Both have had rich and varied careers, so this is a great chance to hear about their experiences. We’ll be taking some questions on the day, but for the best chance of having your questions answered please submit them in the comments below or message one of us organisers.
 
Example questions:
What was it like moving away from academia? And what advice would you give to others thinking about making the transition
What do you think is the most valuable skill you use in your roles as data scientists?
What is your favourite trick in R? E.g. nifty shortcuts, handy functions
What do you look for when joining a new team?
Do you have any advice on making sure we’re bringing R-Ladies principles in to our jobs?
 
We anticipate this event will be well attended so book your place asap. As usual, this event is open to those who identify as a marginalised gender.

Acknowledgements

Thank you to the School of Computing for providing the venue and to Sage for providing pizza.

name: End of year party
description:
Hi ladies,

Let's celebrate the end of the year and start planning the Rladies Brisbane meetup for next year.
Come along on December 20 at Tipplers Tap in South Bank from 5:30pm.

We're looking forward to see you there !

Merry Christmas and happy holidays to everyone!

name: R and RStudio Introductory Workshop
description:
Hi everyone! The first workshop of 2019 is finally here! This is an introductory workshop to R and RStudio, suitable for those who do not have any experience with R. You will learn how to find your way around RStudio, interact with R, manage your environment and install packages.

You are required to bring your own laptop. Please ensure you have the latest version of R and RStudio installed on your machine. You can download and install the latest version of R from (https://www.r-project.org/) and RStudio from (https://www.rstudio.com/). If you have questions please contact us before the event.

We would like to thank Nous Group for providing the venue for this event.

Please register via the following link:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/r-and-rstudio-intro-for-the-rladies-community-in-brisbane-tickets-58628573642

Since spaces are limited, if you are unable to attend, please advise us asap so others in the waiting list can attend!

Look forward to our first workshop of the year!

name: R-Ladies Brisbane Networking
description:
Come along to our first R-Ladies Brisbane networking event! An evening of active networking with friends and other like minded women from all over Brisbane interested in R. Networking events provide an opportunity to make connections, get career advice and support, build confidence and get fresh ideas! name: Spatial data analysis with R [cancelled]
description:
***********
Due to the COVID-19 situation we are cancelling this event.
***********
In this session we have a special international guest!
Dr Reka Solymosi who is a Lecturer in Quantitative Methods at the University of Manchester.

Reka I will talk about how she uses R as a GIS for spatial data analysis. Her main areas of research focus on data about crime, policing, and people's perceptions of place. She will cover descriptive analysis, making thematic and point maps, and some spatial statistics.

Come with your own computer if you want to test this workflow. You will learn about packages such as sf, tmap, leaflet, spatstat and probably some more...!

For more info look at her beautiful R website rekadata.site

We look forward to seeing you there!

name: Adding external images to plots - First RLadies Oslo meetup!
description:
• What we'll do
In this first ever meetup of RLadies-Oslo, current head of RLadies-Oslo will present how she adds neuroimaging images to her plots when visualising data. The approaches used should be easily applicable to other types of plots and images that one may want to combine during data visualisation. Questions are very welcome.

There will be some simple food and drink served, and time to mingle.

• What to bring
No equipment necessary. If you want to give the process a try with your own stuff and get aid from the speaker, bring a laptop/MacBook with R and RStudio installed.

• Important to know
Everyone who accepts our code of conduct (https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#english) is welcome to attend.

name: Hands-on intro to SQL and R with Steph Locke
description:
We are very eager to host Steph Locke from https://itsalocke.com/.

Learn SQL from the comfort of RStudio in this 2.5 hour hands-on workshop. Using SQLite as our database of choice, we'll learn the fundamentals of good data structures, querying single datasets, and combining multiple datasets for getting answers from across your database. Bring your laptop with RStudio and we'll send more info closer to the date on packages to install.

All attendees and speakers must agree to abide by the R-Ladies Code of Conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki

Required software and data:

- Software: R & RStudio

- Packages: RSQLite, rmarkdown

- Data: https://www.kaggle.com/gabrio/board-games-dataset

Please make sure you have the software and packages installed prior to coming, and have downloaded the data to a folder you know how to navigate to.

name: Topic modelling - what is it, and how does VG use it?
description:
Topic models (TM) are powerful tools to programmatically uncover textual structure in what otherwise appear to be just plain unstructured text. The applications of TM are many, like content analysis, article search, and personalisation of content. Isabelle Valette will take us through what topic models are, the way the algorithm works, and how VG has been using it inside and outside the newsroom.

Who is Isabelle?
French data nerd, nature lover and week-end hiker, Isabelle works as a data scientist at the media house VG, one of Norway's largest newspaper. Educated as an economist and transformed into an RLady, a computer scientist and data journalist, Isa loves #rstats. She is passionate about empowering women to become awesome coders.

As we are closing in on Christmas, we will also serve som gingerbread (pepperkaker) and gløgg. Bring your self (and a friend?) and a positive attitude!

name: Building shiny dashboards - with Aurora and Lene
description:
In this workshop, Aurora and Lene will take us through the steps of building a shiny dashboard. We will incrementally build the dashboard, with explanations throughout to help you understand how the components act together.

At the end of the workshop, you should have enough basic understanding of shiny to be able to start building your own shiny dashboard.

Prerequisites:

Laptop with a working installation of Rstudio with the following additional packages installed:
shiny,
shinydashboard,
gapminder,
tidyverse,
DT,
plotly

About the Shiny R-ladies:

Aurora is a diverse data scientist in NextBridge Anlytics. She works with innovative and demanding analytical tasks, and has also worked with system developement. Her background is from physics and she has a PhD in the field of quantum mechanics and condensed matter physics. She has long experience from teaching in academia and began using R some years ago due to a demand for a shiny dashboard.

Lene is a physicist turned data scientist. After analysing data for LHC injections at CERN she joined Nextbridge Analytics in 2016. She enjoys working on a wide range of projects using data and algorithms. After being introduced to R for the second time and tidyverse for the first time she really got into R and after learning about R-ladies she was a part of starting up R-ladies Oslo.

Food and refreshments will be provided, a courtesy of NextBridge Analytics.

We look forward to seeing you all!

name: Bayesian methods for rank and preference data with Valeria Vitelli
description:
Bayesian methods for rank and preference data - from recommendation systems to cancer genomics

Ranking items is crucial for collecting information about preferences in many areas, from marketing to politics. The interest often lies both in producing estimates of the consensus ranking of the items, which is shared among users, and in learning individualized preferences of the users, useful for providing personalized recommendations. In the latter task it is particularly relevant to have posterior distributions of individual rankings, since these can provide an evaluation of the uncertainty associated to the estimates, and thus they can avoid unnecessarily spamming the users.

I will present a statistical model which works well in these situations, and which is able of flexibly handling quite different kind of data. The Bayesian paradigm allows a fully probabilistic analysis, and it easily handles missing data and cluster estimation via augmentation procedures.
Interestingly, this Bayesian framework has also proved to be useful for genomic data integration, since typically heterogeneous microarray data are available from different sources, and their combination allows both to gain statistical power and to strengthen the biological insight.

Valeria Vitelli holds a PhD in statistics from Politecnico di Milano, Italy. She was a postdoc at Ecole Centrale Paris for a year, within a research group funded by Eléctricité de France working on big data problems in the energy sector. She then moved to the University of Oslo, where after a 5 years postdoc period funded from the Norwegian Cancer Society she became associate professor in September 2018. Her experience spans over several areas of mathematics and statistics, including functional data analysis with applications in physiology, machine learning (describing people mobility in dense urbanized areas from mobile phone data), and finally statistical genomics of cancer.

name: Data tidying with dplyr and tidyr - with Athanasia Monika Mowinckel
description:
• What we'll do
This meetup we will go through some data tidying with the {dplyr} and {tidyr} packages from the {tidyverse}. Athanasia (Mo) works a lot with data in various formats, and data cleaning has become a large part of her everyday work. She'll take you though some basic principles, and also highlight the functions that might seem a little hidden, but are truly life savers!

There will be some simple food and drink served, and time to mingle.

• What to bring
No equipment necessary. If you want to give the process a try with your own stuff and get aid from the speaker, bring a laptop/MacBook with R and RStudio installed. She will be switching between talking and live coding, so you can code along.

• Important to know
Everyone who accepts our code of conduct (https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#english) is welcome to attend, regardless of gender.

name: Lightning talks with RLadies Oslo - inspire and be inspired!
description:
• What we'll do
This meetup will be jam packed with shorter talks highlighting what people use R for, either at work or just for fun. R has become so versatile and is used in so many different settings

• List of speakers

-- Aurora Voje: The Shiny DiveR Interactive
-- Chi Zhang (Andrea): Learning from heterogeneous Electronic Health Records using R
-- Bethan Cropp : Local model interpretation with LIME
-- Nina Elisabeth Larsgård : How R saves me a month of work a year - using R when working with data quality management
-- Raoul Wolf : Bayesian structural equation models
-- Lene Norderhaug Drøsdal: surpise talk subject!

• What to bring
No equipment necessary.

There will be some simple food and drink served, and time to mingle.

• Important to know
Everyone who accepts our code of conduct (https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#english) is welcome to attend, regardless of gender.

name: TidyTuesday - with RLadies Oslo
description:
Every Monday the R for Data Science (R4DS) releases a new dataset on their GitHub that has been tamed, but does not always adhere to “tidy” data principles. This dataset will come from an article with an interesting plot. Our goal is to take a look at the raw data, and generate either a copy of the original plot or a novel take on the data! You can obviously use whatever techniques you feel are appropriate, but the data will be organized in a way that tidyverse tools will work well!

We will come together and work in teams helping each other solve this weeks TidyTuesday challenge. TidyTuesdays are a great way to improve R skills and get involved in the community!

* To participate in TidyTuesday, you need to do a few things *

Create and save an image of a plot from R
- Save the code used to recreate your plot (include data tidy steps!)
- Submit the plot and code on Twitter
- Use the #TidyTuesday hashtag (you can also tag me @thomas_mock)
- Browse other submissions and like/comment on their work!

However, that might seem like a lot! So at minimum please submit your plot with the hashtag #TidyTuesday.

* Rules for TidyTuesday *

We welcome all newcomers, enthusiasts, and experts to participate, but be mindful of a few things:

- This is NOT about criticizing the original authors. They are people like you and me and they have feelings. Focus on the data, the charts and improving your own techniques.
- This is NOT about criticizing or tearing down your fellow #RStats practitioners! Be supportive and kind to each other! Like other’s posts and help promote the #RStats community!
- The data set comes from the source article or the source that the article credits. Be mindful that the data is what it is and Tidy Tuesday is designed to help you practice data visualization and basic data wrangling.
- Use the hashtag #TidyTuesday on Twitter if you create your own version and would like to share it.
- Include a picture of the visualisation when you post to Twitter.
- Include a copy of the code used to create your visualization when you post to Twitter. Comment your code wherever possible to help yourself and others understand your process!
- Focus on improving your craft, even if you end up with someting simple! - Make something quick, but purposeful!
- Give credit to the original data source whenever possible.

name: Recap from rstudio::conf 2020 in San Francisco
description:
Welcome to VG house at Akersgata 55 the 3rd of March at 17:00!

In the aftermath of rstudio::conf 2020 in San Francisco, we will take you through the highlights & top announcements, cool new packages, and other fun experiences from the conference and workshops. We will also shortly demo the new Machine Learning framework in RStudio.

As we are at the VG house, Jakob Schmidt, Head of Data and Analytics at VG will present his Data Science teams and some of the cool projects they do.

The agenda will be:
17:00-17:05 Welcome from RLadies
17:05-17:20 Data Science at VG with Jakob Schmidt
17:20-18:10 Highlights from rstudio::conf with Isabelle Valette
18:10-18:30 Lene Drøsdal goes through some results from the survey and closes the event

We will serve pizza and refreshments.

For those we want to hang out, we will go and get a beer at “Stopp Pressen” afterwards.

We look forward to seeing you!

name: Statistrikk: Hard facts by soft materials
description:
Kathrine Frey Frøslie is an associate professor at NMBU (Norwegian University of Life Sciences) and a knitting blogger! Of course she codes in R, and of course she knits what she codes!

"What would a knitted ggplot of the Norwegian Birth Registry's monthly numbers look like?", you may ask. Come to this talk and find out.

Check out her blog at https://www.statistrikk.no!

name: Kick-off meeting
description:
*Agenda*
– Who we are & what we do

description:

name: Intro to Data Visualization w/ R
description:
WHAT TO EXPECT
This workshop will provide a practical introductory overview (with hands-on practice) with making data visualizations in R using ggplot2 (https://ggplot2.org/).

TOPICS
- why everyone talks about data visualization!
- how to pick the right visualization for your data
- overview of visualization packages: ggplot2, ggvis, leaflet, plotly
- why use ggplot2 in R for visualization
- the basics of 'aesthetics'
- the basics of 'geoms'
- other ways to customize the layout of your visualization
- publication quality figures w/ R

AGENDA
6:00–6:10 Meet & Greet | 🍕
6:10–6:20 Future Meetup planning + Set-up
6:20–7:20 Workshop: Intro to Data Visualization w/ R
7:20–7:30 Q&A

* To benefit most from this workshop, please bring your laptop with pre-installed RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/).
Please ping us on Slack (https://rladies-eastlansing.slack.com) or email us ([masked]) with questions, if any.

Sponsor: Social Science Data Analytics, MSU https://ssda.msu.edu/

name: Intro to Tidy Data w/ R
description:
WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you'd like to start working with data in R w/o learning all the programming details first!!
- If you have a neat data set you'd like to explore and visualize!
- If you are a current R user but only familiar w/ base R!
- If you are unfamiliar with pipes
- If you have heard of tidyverse/dplyr/tidyr/tibble/ggplot but haven't had the chance to get started!

*If any/all of this is true, this workshop might be for you!*

WHAT we are planning!
- basics of tidyverse & ’tidy data’
- reshaping data with tidyr: gather, spread, separate, unite
- exploring data with dplyr: filter, select, mutate, transmute, arrange, summarise, group_by
- how tidy data talks to ggplot
- a quick summary of ggplot2
- finally, publication quality figures w/ R!

AGENDA
6:00–6:15 Meet & Greet | 🍕| Set-up
6:15–6:25 Who we are | Announcements | What's next
6:25–7:25 Workshop: Intro to Tidy Data w/ R
7:25–7:30 Any more Qs? How to reach us to continue this conversation!

*To benefit most from this workshop*
1. please bring your laptop w/
2. pre-installed R & RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/)
3. tidyverse package (https://www.tidyverse.org/)
4. gapminder dataset package (installation: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/gapminder/; about gapminder: https://www.gapminder.org/data/)
* Having trouble with installation & set-up? Ping us on Slack!

name: RStats Workshop Series: Part I (Jan28—>Feb04!)
description:
WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you'd like to start working with data in R w/o learning all the programming details first!!
- If you have a neat data set you'd like to explore w/ basic statistics!
- If you are getting started with base R and want to learn more #rstats!

* If any of this is true, this workshop might be for you!
* Come EARLY (545p) for set-up, questions reg. tidyverse

WHAT are we planning?
*RStats Workshop: Part I*
- getting started with R
- exploratory statistics: measures of central tendency & variability, correlations, multi-variate stats
- visualizing statistical analyses: histograms, boxplots/violin plots, scatterplots, bar graphs, saving plots
- Excel/SAS/SPSS vs R?

- Parts II, III of 'Learning Statistics with R' by Dani Navarro (https://learningstatisticswithr.com/book).
- Statistical exploration of the gapminder dataset w/ R

*RStats Workshop: Coming up next*
- Probability Distributions & skew, kurtosis
- Inferential Statistics: hypothesis testing, p-value, confidence intervals
- Handling Missing data: imputation
- Parametric (e.g., ANOVA) & Non-parametric statistical tests
- Principal Component Analysis (PCA) using ggbiplot

AGENDA
6:00–6:15 Meet & Greet | 🍕| Set-up
6:15–6:25 Who we are | Announcements | What's next
6:25–7:25 Workshop: Intro to Statistics w/ R
